com.innowhere.jnieasy.core.data
Interface NativeStringBuffer

All Superinterfaces:
CanBeNativeCapable, NativeCapable, NativeFieldContainer, NativeObjectFieldContainer, NativeSingleFieldContainer, NativeStringBased
All Known Subinterfaces:
NativeStringBufferAnsi, NativeStringBufferUnicode
public interface NativeStringBuffer
extends NativeStringBased

The NativeStringBuffer is the interface implemented by native capable classes working as wrappers of java.lang.StringBuffer objects.

The framework defines an internal native class supporting ANSI and UNICODE encodings/sizes.

Author:
Jose M. Arranz Santamaria

Method Detail

getStringBuffer

java.lang.StringBuffer getStringBuffer()
Returns the internal StringBuffer object synchronized with the native memory if instance is native.

Current implementation is:

return (StringBuffer)getValue();

Returns:
the internal StringBuffer object. Never is null.
See Also:
NativeSingleFieldContainer.getValue()

setStringBuffer

void setStringBuffer(java.lang.StringBuffer value)
Sets the internal StringBuffer object synchronizing the native memory with the new value if instance is native.

Current implementation is:

setValue(value);

Parameters:
value - the new value. Can not be null.
See Also:
NativeSingleFieldContainer.setValue(Object)

getCharacter

char getCharacter(int index,
                  int fetchMode)
Returns the character at the specified index synchronized with the native memory if instance is native using the specified fetch mode.

Fetch values FAST, EMBEDDED and DEEP have the same behavior: native memory is read and internal value is synchronized before return.

Parameters:
index - the zero-based index of the character.
fetchMode - the fetch mode.
Returns:
the character at the specified index.
See Also:
Fetch

setCharacter

void setCharacter(int index,
                  char value,
                  int unFetchMode)
Sets the character at the specified index synchronizing the native memory with the new value if instance is native.

Unfetch values FAST, EMBEDDED and DEEP have the same behavior: native memory is updated with the new value.

Parameters:
index - the zero-based index of the character.
value - the new value.
unFetchMode - the "unfetch" mode.

getCharacter

char getCharacter(int index)
Returns the character element at the specified index synchronized with the native memory if instance is native.

Current implementation calls getCharacter(int,int) using the default fetch mode.

Parameters:
index - the zero-based index of the character.
Returns:
the character at the specified index.
See Also:
NativeManager.getDefaultFetchMode()

setCharacter

void setCharacter(int index,
                  char value)
Sets the character at the specified index synchronizing the native memory with the new value if instance is native.

Current implementation calls setCharacter(int,char,int) using the default "unfetch" mode.

Parameters:
index - the zero-based index of the character.
value - the new value.
See Also:
NativeManager.getDefaultUnFetchMode()
